prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The median FWHM for SMGs and quasars at these redshifts is ~500-600 km/s (Coppin et al. 2008, Bothwell et al. 2013). There might be addtional velocity broadening in our sources given their powerful quasar-driven [OIII] outflows. Our requested resolution bandwidth of 100 km/s is sufficient to measure the lines in all varieties of possible outcomes.

We request a moderately compact array configuration to maximize the fluxes and signal-to-noise ratios per beam. The galaxy sizes in upper-J CO lines are expected to be small, R ~ 2-3 kpc (Tacconi et al. 2008; Engel et al. 2010). [CI] (2-1) and the dust continuum could be more extended like some low-J CO or radio continuum emissions from SMG, with R ~ 3-10 kpc (Chapman et al. 2004; Ivison et al. 2011). With a ~1 arcsec beam corresponding to ~8.3 kpc on source, we will spatially resolve extended emission in cases with a major blowout or recent major merger.

Our science goals are to measure the CO (7-6) and [CI] (2-1) emission lines and adjacent dust continuum at ~385 microns in the quasar rest frame (z ~ 2.4). We estimate line and continuum fluxes from published observations of SMGs and luminous blue quasars at redshifts similar to our targets (e.g., Coppin et al. 2008, Walter et al. 2011, Bothwell et al. 2013, Alaghband-Zadeh et al. 2013, Swinbank et al. 2014). Our quasar targets are very luminous and potentially young, so they might have significantly stronger gas and dust emissions than these comparison samples. However, we adopt conservatively low RMS thresholds to ensure that we can measure emission equivalent to faint SMGs in a worst case scenario. Thus even non-detections will be valuable - implying that the galaxies are very depleted of gas and dust compared to the high quasar luminosities.
For the spectral lines, we assume FWHM = 1000 km/s, which is ~2x broader than the median for SMGs and quasars but might occur in our quasar targets due to outflows. (We do not expect velocities much larger than this in a mass-loaded molecular outflow, in spite of the high speeds seen in the ionized [OIII] gas.) A channel width of 100 km/s is easily sufficient to resolve the important velocity structure. We conservatively adopt a continuum flux equal to 1/3 the median for SMGs at these redshifts, ~0.67 mJy (Figure 1), and an integrated line flux 0.6 Jy km/s for a weak SMG (Bothwell et al. 2013). With ~10 resolution elements across the line, the OT sensitivity calculations show that in this *worst case* scenario the lines are easily detectable with useful constraints on the FHWMs.
We note that the CO (7-6) 238.55 GHz and [CI] (2-1) 239.35 GHz emission lines are about 1000 km/s apart and would blend in the situation described above with FWHM = 1000 km/s. However, our measurement of CO (4-3) in Band 4 is largely redundant with CO (7-6) here. If blending does occur, we will use CO (4-3) as our main indicator of the upper-J CO kinematics and use its profile to disentangle the CO (7-6) and [CI] (2-1) lines where they overlap. We will still gain valuable information on the strengths and profiles of both CO (7-6) and [CI] (2-1) and the Band 6 continuum point is important to retain for our science. These lines are our best options.

The median FWHM for SMGs and quasars at these redshifts is ~500-600 km/s (Coppin et al. 2008, Bothwell et al. 2013). With a ~1 arcsec beam corresponding to ~8.3 kpc on source, we will spatially resolve extended emission in cases with a major blowout or recent major merger.

Thus even non-detections will be valuable - implying that the galaxies are very depleted of gas and dust compared to the high quasar luminosities.

(We do not expect velocities much larger than this in a mass-loaded molecular outflow, in spite of the high speeds seen in the ionized [OIII] gas.) prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Red quasars are believed to mark a transition stage in massive galaxy formation when a blowout of gas and dust truncates the initial dusty starburst and reveals a visibly luminous quasar in the galactic center. We identified a population of extremely red quasars (ERQs) with UV--MIR colors like dust obscured galaxies (DOGs) plus other exotic properties that include powerful galaxy-scale outflows revealed by the broadest and most blueshifted [OIII] 5007 lines ever reported (with FWHMs and blue wings reaching 5000 km/s). We propose exploratory observations of two ERQs at z=2.4 to measure their CO(4-3), CO(7-6) and [CI](2-1) emission lines and adjacent continua at ~385 and 625 microns rest. Our broad goals are to characterize the ERQs compared to luminous blue quasars and star-forming SMGs at similar redshifts, test their alleged youth in starburst-quasar evolution schemes, and study the effects of powerful ionized-gas outflows on the host galaxies. We will specifically 1) search for gaseous blowouts or extreme kinematics in the line profiles, and 2) estimate cold dust masses, molecular gas masses, fractions of molecular gas participating in star formation, and star formation rates.
